transcripts.text: Hi, welcome to C-Von News Network.  I'm here with Brandon Booth and I'm Leonard Bakani.  We just attended a protest at North Bend, Washington.  And for the most part, there were not a whole lot going on.  It was a peaceful protest.  I would estimate there was maybe over 500.  It was attended by people of all walks of life.  even with families with children of all ages.  I did speak to police command, and they said that, except for a few incidents, it was pretty much a peaceful protest.  I'm here with Captain Almquist.  He's the incident commander here at this protest.  Captain, what are your thoughts and your comments about this protest?  Looks pretty peaceful so far.

Yeah, I think it's going really well.  The organizer, we've been working with her for a while on this.  She's very passionate about what she wants to message, and we've established a really good relationship with her.  Remember to float!  Remember to register to vote.  We need to vote someone into office who will look at people, at their citizens, crying out for help and do something about it.  Power to the people!  Power to the freaking people!  And so far, everyone's doing a great job of just staying on the sidewalk and minding their business, but also getting their message out.
Right.  So there's been no incidents so far?
Very minor things that aren't really worth saying, just a few little things, but nothing major.
There was a heavy police presence.  Incident command indicated that they received mutual aid from all agencies in the surrounding area, so it was taken care of.
We have mutual aid assistance from Issaquah, Algona, Pacific, Kittitas County, and Department of Fish and Wildlife.

We also saw a lot of patriots protecting the storefronts.  They were there to make sure that there's no vandalism or terrorism going on with the businesses and to protect the people.  This is Denny.  He's out in front of a store and it's all boarded up.  I noticed that he's openly caring, which is their right to do in the state of Washington.  Denny, what do you have to say?

I think a lot of this is ridiculous.  We already know the unfortunate thing happened in Minnesota.  It's been wall to wall in the media for 10 days.  We know about some of this going on.  We don't need people tearing up our city.  They don't need to come out here and break windows.  And we've been through enough with the COVID stuff with Inslee locking us down, which is ridiculous.  I just think it's kind of asinine for all this to go on and them to break windows and destroy things in our community.  North Bend's a small town.  I lived here my whole life.  I hate seeing this boarded up to look like a hurricane's going to hit.  These business owners didn't need to do this.  Why?  And now they're saying that they've dropped off these agitators or somewhere in town and the police have them under surveillance.  I'm imagining when the lights go out, when the sun goes down, they're going to start breaking things up.
Now, I heard that business owners, shop owners received a briefing from the police department.  What was that all about?

Well, they're just in it.  If they feel threatened and they break their windows out and come inside their businesses, They're supposed to call 911.  There's a lot of police force here, about 60 of them.  So they'll be right on them.  They're just in here to protect their businesses, their livelihoods.  So it's unfortunate that they have to do this.  Our Snoqualmie North Bend Police Department are great guys.  And so they've got Kittitas County here, Washington State Patrol.  They've got the game department here.  A lot of taxpayer dollars are getting flushed down the toilet right now for all this police presence.  Everybody's got to get paid.  I don't know.  I'm just sitting here watching.  It's sad.  I grew up here.  I watched parades go down this street.  Now it's getting crazy out here.  Right, right.  It's all coming out of that cesspool of Seattle and all the brainwashing down there.
I'm here with Clayton Littlejohn.  He's known by the locals as the town mayor.  Clayton, do you have anything to say?

Yeah, I guess so.  I guess if they want to have a protest, it's all good to have a protest.  It's a matter of not breaking up our town.  You know, if you want to protest in peace, great.  All these people are hard-working people.  They got a livelihood here and I don't see the sense in busting up the town.
Right.  I noticed that the business behind this is boarded up.  Are you here to help make sure there's no vandalism going on?

Yeah, kind of.  We're just kind of a bunch of guys got together today just to protect our community.  It's a matter of respect.  Okay.  Coming together with the, you know, these people worked their whole lives to get what they got here and senseless breaking of windows and robbing their stores doesn't make sense to me.
Absolutely.

You know, we don't, you know, I don't believe in going to somebody's town and busting up and stealing all the stuff.  I mean, I don't get it.  I've worked hard my whole life for what I got and I don't want to see these people lose what they've got because of some, a few irresponsible, I'm going to use the word morons.  Right.  You know, they just, It just doesn't make sense to me.  If you want to protest, it's all good.  Hear your voice and do that, but there's no sense of the violence.  It doesn't make sense to me.
I'm here with Elvis, and he's out here in front of a boarded business and just making sure that everything's going okay.  Elvis, what do you have to say?  Why are you here?

Well, I'm here to support everybody, really.  You know, the protesters out here have every right to have a peaceful protest out here, and, you know, we're just out watching, I guess, and making sure, you know, our business owner friends here, everybody's safe, and... You know, giving everybody the opportunity to do what they want peacefully.  It's a beautiful thing.
We have Doug Hockenberry.  He's a store owner.  Doug, what do you have to say?  A very interesting day.
I didn't think there would be so many people, but there are, and I think that's great.  Different signs, different stances for the liberties that we have.
I'm here to...
support the youth, the students that I have been involved with at Mount Sinai High School.
So it's been a peaceful protest so far.
Were you concerned?  Very much.
I didn't really have a concern.
This is a good, great community that takes care of each other.
support each other.  I'm here with Aaron Rapp, the owner of North End Bakery.  So I see that you're holding some donuts, Aaron.  What's going on?

That's right.  So we're handing out free donut holes today.  We've got a Black Lives Matter protest going on from two to five here in downtown North Bend.  And the North Bend Bakery decided to spread some cheer and some happiness by handing out free donuts to everybody.
Right on.  So but for the most part, it was a peaceful protest.  and no incidents to speak of.
No, it was a very good event for the people of North Bend and the police department was very pleased with everything that transpired at the event.

I would like to share, however, that when we first got there, I was approached by Antifa, about five or six of them, and one in particular male, had approached me, was walking towards me in an aggressive manner.  He looked angry.  And he was physically restrained by one of his cohorts.  And what he said to me was, because of your article, The heat is on you, man.  So I don't know exactly what that meant, but it sounded kind of ominous and threatening.  The incident was reported to police.  They indicated that they saw the incident happen, so it's recorded.  One thing to note, Seavine did receive an email from the mother of a female in the pictures that we posted yesterday.  She claimed her daughter was not Antifa.  That's the way she always dresses along with her boyfriend.  So you decide.  We laid out the facts and we want our viewers to make that determination.  Brandon, did you have anything to add?

I feel that with us notifying the police department of what we saw was definitely a part of the police present being as large as it was at the event.  And they were on every corner watching, even during the incident with Leonard.  They even called Leonard while we were walking away from it to notify Leonard that they actually saw what happened and wanted us to know that.

Yeah, we're very grateful to the men and women in blue that helped protect North Bend.  I think they handled the situation with professionalism.  Do you have a message for the people who want to peacefully demonstrate and uh the townspeople?

well we fully understand that everybody has a message whether it be this platform or another right and to be able to do that in a peaceful manner and the way that this has been going this far to this particular time.  We fully support any messaging that they want to do and as long as, like I said, it's done peacefully, we're extremely happy with the community and so far the people that have decided to come and engage in this.
